questions.text: A patient with an Alvarado score of 8 was admitted to the hospital for surgery. In this scoring system, what is the score assigned to the symptom of vomiting?

choices.text: Not included in the scoring system

questions.solution:
Vomiting/nausea is given a score of 1 as per the Alvarado Scoring System.

The Alvarado Scoring System is the clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis. It is composed of 8 components with a total score of 10.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman at 8 weeks of gestation presents with an increased frequency of vomiting, associated with retching. She shows no signs of dehydration or volume depletion. Which of the following factors is unlikely to cause the above symptoms in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a 21-year-old woman presenting with an increased frequency of vomiting and retching, in the first trimester, with no signs of dehydration or volume depletion is suggestive of early type of hyperemesis gravidarum. Decreased gastric motility is associated with this condition. 

Hyperemesis gravidarum is defined as excessive vomiting during pregnancy that interferes with daily activities and/or worsens the mother's health.

Theories involved include:

  1. Hormonal - Excess progesterone causes cardiac sphincter relaxation and gastric fluid retention due to impaired gastric motility. Excess of chorionic gonadotropin or higher biological activity of hCG is also associated.
  2. Psychogenic factors probably aggravates nausea once it begins. 
  3. Dietetic deficiency - due to low carbohydrate reserve 
  4. Decreased gastric motility 
  5. Allergic or immunological basis 

Unrelenting nausea and vomiting that is severe enough to cause weight loss, dehydration, ketosis, alkalosis, or hypokalemia is known as hyperemesis gravidarum. It is most commonly seen in a first pregnancy, young age, low body mass, history of migraine/motion sickness, positive family history, hydatidiform mole, low body mass, and multi-fetal gestation

Cases are grouped into (a) Early - no evidence of dehydration and starvation and (b) Late (moderate to severe)- evidence of dehydration and starvation are present 

Symptoms include vomiting which is increased in frequency with retching. Epigastric pain, oliguria, and constipation may occur. Signs include features of dehydration and ketoacidosis: Dry coated tongue, sunken eyes, acetone smell in breath, tachycardia, and hypotension.

Management of hyperemesis gravidarum: 

  • Mild to moderate symptoms can be treated with dietary modifications, vitamin B6 with doxylamine/diphenhydramine.
  • Severe cases need IV hydration with thiamine and parenteral ondansetron/metoclopramide/promethazine. 
  • Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV  is given in case of hypotension or intractable vomiting. Oral prednisolone is also used in severe cases.

questions.text: A 20-year-old nonsmoker male patient with a past history of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) has been scheduled for surgery. For postoperative pain, he was given opioids. What score is assigned to this patient based on the Apfel scoring system used to predict the risk of PONV?
questions.solution:
According to the Apfel scoring system used to predict the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), this patient will be given a score of 3.

Apfel scoring system is used for the risk stratification based on four factors, each factor is given a score of 1. The incidence of PONV with the presence of 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 risk factors is about 10%, 20%, 40%, 60%, and 80%, respectively. The four factors are:

Risk Factors Score
Female 1
Nonsmoking status, 1
History of PONV 1
Use of postoperative opioids 1
Sum  0 to 4

PONV is the second most common complaint after postoperative pain that a patient presents with. It occurs in about 20-30% of the general surgical population and its incidence is markedly raised in those with predisposing risk factors. Prevention is better than cure.

Risk factors for PONV:

In addition to the above-mentioned factors, those of a younger age (<50 years) have delayed gastric emptying due to diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, pregnancy, increased intracranial tension, etc. Surgical procedures such as cholecystectomy, laparoscopy, gynaecological surgeries, and breast surgery are also associated with PONV.

The Society for Ambulatory Anesthesia (SAMBA) provides extensive guidelines for the management of PONV, which includes:

  • 5-HT3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones
  • Dexamethasone
  • Neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists - Aprepitant
  • Acupuncture and acupressure can reduce PONV incidence and medication requirements.

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of distal small bowel obstruction?

choices.text: Frequent vomiting with no abdominal distention
Moderate vomiting with crescendo type pain

questions.solution:
Feculent vomiting is a characteristic feature of distal small bowel obstruction.

Features of different levels of SB obstruction:

Level of SBO High Middle Low/distant
Type of vomiting  Frequent vomiting. Moderate vomiting.  Vomiting late, feculent. 
Abdominal distension No distention Moderate distention.  Marked distention. 
Pain associated Intermittent pain but not classic crescendo type.  Intermittent pain (crescendo, colicky) with free intervals.  Variable pain; may not be classic or crescendo type. 

Small bowel obstruction (SBO) is one of the most common disorders affecting the small bowel. It is classified as either mechanical obstruction or paralytic ileus. A mechanical obstruction refers to an extrinsic or intrinsic barrier that stops the intestinal contents from moving freely. A neurogenic failure of peristalsis to propel intestinal contents without mechanical obstruction results in paralytic (or adynamic) ileus.

Blood-stained vomiting (hematemesis) is associated with upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage, commonly originating in the stomach or esophagus. The blood may be dark or bright red, suggesting that the source is proximal to the ligament of Treitz. If blood remains in the stomach for a prolonged period, gastric acid will convert the haemoglobin to acid hematin, resulting in coffee-ground vomitus (Option C).

questions.text:
A G4P3 mother who conceived via ART presents with complaints of excessive nausea and vomiting in her first trimester. She gives a past history of vomiting in all her previous pregnancies but she believes it was worse this time. Her vitals are stable and no other complications were noted. What is the next best step in managing this case?

ART- Assisted Reproductive Technology

choices.text: Start her on IM promethazine 25 mg

questions.solution:
The next step in managing the case of a G4P3 mother who conceived via ART, presenting with complaints of severe nausea and vomiting in the first trimester, more than in any of her prior pregnancies with stable vitals and no other complications, is to get an ultrasound done. It helps in evaluating the viability of the pregnancy, checking for multiple gestations (which are more common with ART and can cause more severe nausea and vomiting), and ruling out any complications such as a molar pregnancy, which can present with exaggerated pregnancy symptoms.

History of ovulation-inducing drugs for infertility or the use of ART have a higher chance of multifetal pregnancies. They usually present with increased nausea and vomiting in the early months due to increased levels of serum human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG). They also present with palpitations, shortness of breath, increased swelling of legs, unusual rate of uterine growth and excessive fetal movements.

On palpation, the height of the uterus is more than the period of amenorrhea. The clinical diagnosis is almost certain if too many fetal parts are palpated or if two fetal heads or three fetal poles are discovered.

Most people find that their symptoms can be relieved by eating dry toast or biscuits and avoiding foods that are high in fat and/or spice. It is beneficial to take 100 mg of vitamin B1 daily as a supplement. Antiemetic medications, such as trifluoperazine, ondansetron and promethazine are useful.

Other options:

Once a patient is diagnosed with hyperemesis gravidarum she is admitted to the hospital (option A). After vomiting stops, oral feeding is stopped for at least 24 hours and IV fluids are started (option D). About three litres of fluid total—half of which is Ringer's solution and the other half is 5% dextrose are given. Additional crystalloids should be added in an amount equal to the amount of vomitus and urine in a 24-hour period. The antiemetic drug promethazine (Phenergan) 25 mg may be administered twice or thrice daily intramuscularly (option C).

questions.text: An anti-emetic medication is administered as a transdermal patch to a cancer patient 48 hours prior to the start of her chemotherapy session in order to prevent chemotherapy-induced emesis. Which of the following drugs is administered?
questions.solution:
Granisetron, a 5HT3 antagonist, is available as a transdermal formulation for use as an antiemetic in chemotherapy-induced emesis. It has to be applied 24-48 hours before chemotherapy and worn for up to 7 days.

During chemotherapy, there is cell lysis and 5HT (serotonin) is released from the gut mucosa. The released serotonin acts on the 5HT3 receptors, activating the vagal afferents in the gut that carry the emetogenic impulses to the nucleus tractus solitarius and chemoreceptor trigger zone. The selective blockade of 5HT3 receptors reduces the emetogenic impulse.

Other options:

Options A and C: Netupitant and Rolapitant are potent NK1 receptor antagonists that prevent delayed-phase chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. They are used in combination with a 5HT3 antagonist and dexamethasone. They are used as a single-dose oral formulation one hour before chemotherapy.

Option B: Palonosetron is a 5HT3 antagonist having maximum potency in chemotherapy-induced vomiting. It has a high affinity for 5HT3 and is also the longest-acting 5HT3 antagonist. This makes it more effective in delayed emesis associated with chemotherapy. Palonosetron combined with the NK1 receptor antagonist netupitant, is recently FDA-approved for treating acute and delayed nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child who presented with recurrent episodes of vomiting was diagnosed with cyclic vomiting syndrome. Which of the following is not included in the diagnostic criteria of cyclic vomiting syndrome?

choices.text: Associated with severe abdominal pain and neurological abnormalities
Minimum of 3 vomiting episodes during a 6 month period
Return to baseline health in between vomiting episodes
Stereotypical pattern and symptoms in the individual patient

questions.solution:
The presence of severe abdominal pain and neurological abnormalities is not part of the diagnostic criteria of cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS). It is considered a red flag. 

Cyclic vomiting syndrome is an idiopathic disorder associated with episodic vomiting, usually of sudden onset and high intensity or frequency (4 episodes /hour or 12-15 episodes/day) of vomiting, which eventually returns to baseline in between attacks. 

Diagnostic criteria include:

  • Episodes (2 or more) of severe nausea and vomiting that last for hours or days over the course of 6 months.
  • Stereotypical pattern and symptoms in the individual patient
  • Episodes are separated by weeks to months
  • Return to baseline between episodes
  • Not related to another disorder

Red flags include:

  • Abdominal tenderness, bilious emesis, and/or severe abdominal pain
  • Attacks triggered by a concurrent illness, fasting, or a high-protein meal
  • Anomalies of the nervous system (mental status changes, ophthalmic asymmetry/focal changes, ataxia)
  • An abnormal pattern or a decline from the patient's usual presentation to a more persistent or chronic pattern.

Treatment:

  • Supportive care- fluid and electrolyte management, resuming enteral nutrition as soon as possible, medications like antiemetics (ondansetron and granisetron).
  • Abortive care- antimigraine medications (sumatriptan) in patients with a family history of migraines.
  • Lifestyle measures- Reassurance and anticipatory guidance and avoidance and managing of triggers.

questions.text: An infant presents with vomiting, lethargy, severe acidosis, and a characteristic odor emanating from his vomitus and body fluids. On further evaluation, plasma analysis revealed an excess of C5-carnitine. What characteristic odor is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of an infant presenting with vomiting, lethargy, severe acidosis and plasma analysis revealing an excess of C5-carnitine (isovalerylcarnitine) suggests a diagnosis of isovaleric acidemia which is associated with the characteristic sweaty feet or rancid cheese odour.

Isovaleric acidemia is caused by a lack of the enzyme isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase (IVD), which affects the leucine breakdown pathway, causing intermediates to accumulate. Excess protein consumption causes isovaleryl-CoA to accumulate, which is then hydrolyzed to isovalerate and excreted.

These intermediates are responsible for clinical symptoms such as vomiting, severe acidosis, and sweaty feet or rancid cheese odour. Vomiting that is severe enough may indicate pyloric stenosis. Laboratory findings include ketoacidosis, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and hypoglycemia.

The diagnosis is made by demonstrating significant increases in isovaleric acid metabolites (isovalerylglycine, 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid) in body fluids, particularly urine. Isovalerylcarnitine (C5-carnitine) is the most abundant compound in plasma. A molecular analysis of the IVD gene can also confirm the diagnosis.

L-carnitine is the preferred treatment because it aids in the removal of isovaleric acid in the form of isovalerylcarnitine, which is excreted in the urine.

Other options:

Option A: Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to a deficiency of branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDH). This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids valine, leucine, isoleucine, and alloisoleucine. The peculiar burnt sugar odour of urine is characteristic of this disease.

Option B: Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal-dominant condition due to a deficiency of the enzyme 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase which catalyzes the reaction of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate to homogentisic acid in the tyrosine catabolism pathway. It leads to the accumulation of the metabolite hawkinsin. The swimming pool odour of the urine is characteristic of this condition.

Option C: Type I tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Children present with mild mental retardation, liver failure, and hypoglycemia. Urine typically has a boiled cabbage odour. Boiled cabbage odour can also be found in cases of hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with a cyclical pattern of hyperemesis for the last 2 years. He says that taking a hot shower helps to temporarily relieve the symptoms. He gives a history of drug abuse for the last 10 years. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 40-year-old male with a history of chronic drug abuse presenting with a cyclical pattern of hyperemesis for the last 2 years, temporarily relieved by taking hot water showers is suggestive of cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome (CHS).

Cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome (CHS) is a condition in which a patient experiences cyclical nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain after using cannabis. The pattern of hyperemesis is cyclical, occurring every few weeks to months, and is relieved by hot baths or showers. It is characterized by years of prior cannabis use and the resolution of symptoms takes place once the drug is stopped.

The current theory suggests that CHS is caused by chronic overstimulation of endocannabinoid receptors, resulting in disruptions in the body's intrinsic control of nausea and vomiting. Involvement of the transient receptor potential vanilloid-1 (TRPV1) nociceptor system in the peripheral nervous system is also noted.

The changes in the composition of cannabis over the years with a decrease in cannabidiol (CBD) and an increase in tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) have played a significant role in the development of CHS. This has led to a drastic increase in cannabis use.

One of the main challenges in managing CHS is its resistance to standard antiemetic medications like metoclopramide and ondansetron, which are used in both emergency and primary care settings.

Treatment includes intravenous hydration and proton pump inhibitors for gastritis. Capsaicin is used as a potential analgesic. However, long-term recovery is possible only with complete abstinence from cannabis.

questions.text: The ABG value of a patient presenting with vomiting is likely to correspond to which of the following areas in the given acid-base nomogram?
questions.solution:
The image shows the acid-base nomogram, which is plotted as arterial HCO3- against arterial blood pH. The area marked 'C' is suggestive of metabolic alkalosis, which is seen in vomiting.

In the area marked 'C', pH is above the normal limits (7.35–7.45) and thus implies the presence of alkalosis. Plasma HCO3-  is higher than the normal limits (22–28 mEq/L). This implies that the alkalosis is due to an increase in the plasma HCO3- and is thus metabolic in origin. 

Net gain of [HCO3-] or loss of nonvolatile acid (usually HCl by vomiting) from the extracellular fluid causes metabolic alkalosis. HCO3− secretion in the small bowel cannot begin when vomiting results in the loss of HCl from the stomach; as a result, HCO3− is retained in the extracellular fluid.

Compensatory responses for primary metabolic disorders move the PaCO2 in the same direction as the change in HCO3−. Electrolyte abnormalities seen are hypocalcemia, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia.

Clinical features include:

  • Mental confusion
  • Reduced level of alertness 
  • Predisposition to: seizures, paresthesia, muscular cramping, tetany, arrhythmias, and hypoxemia in COPD

Management of metabolic alkalosis involves:

  • Correction of the underlying cause
  • Remove factors causing an increase in HCO3- absorption like extracellular fluid volume contraction or hypokalemia.
  • In case of excess fluid administration, renal loss can be encouraged by the administration of acetazolamide.

Causes of metabolic alkalosis:

Loss of hydrogen:

  • Gastrointestinal loss:
    • Removal of gastric secretions, such as in vomiting or gastric aspiration
    • Chloride-losing diarrhea
    • Gastrocolic fistula
  • Renal loss:
    • Loop or thiazide diuretics
    • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice)
    • Hypercalcemia, including the milk-alkali syndrome
  • H+ movement into cells:
    • Hypokalemia

Exogenous Alkali:

  • Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids
  • Massive blood transfusion
  • Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome
 

Other options:

Option A: (Area B- corresponds to chronic respiratory acidosis) An increase in PaCO2 and a decrease in pH indicates respiratory acidosis, which occurs due to severe pulmonary disease, respiratory muscle exhaustion, or anomalies in ventilatory control. Renal adaptation raises the [HCO3-] in chronic respiratory acidosis (>24 h) by 4 mmol/L for each 10-mmHg increase in PaCO2. It is seen in conditions like emphysema, pneumoconiosis and bronchitis. 

Option C: (Area F- corresponds to metabolic acidosis). Increased endogenous acid production (such as lactate and ketoacids), loss of bicarbonate (as in diarrhoea), or accumulation of endogenous acids due to low excretion of net acid by the kidney (chronic kidney disease) can all lead to metabolic acidosis.

Option D: (Area E- corresponds to chronic respiratory alkalosis). Respiratory alkalosis is induced by a process involving hyperventilation resulting in a decrease in PaCO2 and an increase in HCO3−/ PaCO2 ratio, thus increasing the pH. Causes include anxiety-hyperventilation, fear, hypoxic stimulation and pulmonary causes such as pulmonary embolism, pneumothorax and COPD exacerbations. Chronic respiratory alkalosis occurs when hypocapnia persists for >3–5 days.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented with persistent vomiting and intractable hiccups. She had 15–20 episodes of vomiting per day with a weight loss of 3 kg. A detailed gastrointestinal evaluation was done but the results were insignificant. Neurological examination revealed bilateral optic neuritis with extensive transverse myelitis. Which of the following antibodies is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old female patient who presented with intractable hiccups and persistent vomiting of up to 15–20 episodes per day with a weight loss of 3 kg and neurological examination that revealed bilateral optic neuritis with extensive transverse myelitis points towards the diagnosis or area postrema syndrome seen in patients with neuromyelitis optica (NMO). AQP4 (aquaporin-4) IgG antibodies are associated with this condition.

Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorders (NMOSDs) are a group of immune-mediated inflammatory disorders affecting the central nervous system that commonly target the optic nerves and spinal cord. It is characterized by recurrent attacks of optic neuritis (ON) and myelitis and is associated with a pathogenic antibody specific to the astrocytic water channel aquaporin-4 (AQP4). 

One of the core clinical features of neuromyelitis optic spectrum disorder (NMOSD) is area postrema syndrome (APS), which is defined as uncontrollable nausea, vomiting, and hiccups lasting >48 hours.

The area postrema (AP) which is present in the dorsal medullary tegmentum, is made up of chemosensitive neurons that modulate fluid balance, osmoregulation, and hiccups. It is highly rich in AQP4 water channel, so it is usually involved in AQP4 antibody–positive individuals.

Plasmapheresis or 3-5 days of methylprednisolone pulse therapy are used to treat acute attacks. Long-term immunotherapy must be initiated in double-positive NMOSD + APS as it is associated with further frequent relapses. Eculizumab, inebilizumab, and satralizumab are used as maintenance therapy.

Core Clinical Characteristics:

  1. Optic neuritis- usually bilateral and cause severe visual loss.
  2. Acute myelitis- may be severe, transverse and typically longitudinally extensive involving three or more contiguous vertebral segments.
  3. Area postrema syndrome: episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups, nausea or vomiting
  4. Acute brainstem syndrome
  5. Symptomatic narcolepsy  associated with NMOSD-typical diencephalic MRI lesions

Diagnostic Criteria for NMOSD associated with AQP4-IgG

  1. At least 1 core clinical characteristic
  2. A positive test for AQP4-IgG using the best available detection method (cell-based assay)
  3. Exclusion of alternative diagnoses

questions.text: A young boy presented with severe vomiting after eating a local unripe fruit given to him by a friend visiting from Jamaica. His blood glucose level dropped to 45 mg/dl. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this child's presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young boy who presented with severe vomiting and hypoglycemia following the ingestion of a local unripe Jamaican fruit points towards the diagnosis of Jamaican vomiting sickness. It occurs due to ingestion of the unripe ackee fruit that contains heat-stable toxins hypoglycin A and B.

Ingestion of unripe Ackee fruit that grows on the Blighia sapida tree, a common ingredient in West African and Jamaican cuisine may result in the metabolic syndrome known as Jamaican vomiting sickness.

Unripe ackee fruit contains the heat-stable toxins hypoglycin A and B. Hypoglycin inactivates medium- and short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, inhibiting β-oxidation and causing hypoglycemia. 

Clinical manifestations include frequent vomiting and altered mental status; severe cases can result in coma, hypothermia, seizures, and even death.

Treatment is primarily supportive since there is no particular antidote for hypoglycin. Hypoglycemia should be monitored carefully and treated with dextrose. Intravenous fluids should be provided to prevent dehydration and antiemetics from alleviating symptoms. 

Given below is the image of the Ackee fruit:

Other options:

Option A: Refsum disease is a rare neurologic disorder that results in the accumulation of phytanic acid, which is found in dairy products, ruminant fat and meat.

Option C: Accumulation of C26-C38 polyenoic fatty acids in the brain tissue is seen in Zellweger syndrome. It occurs due to an inherited loss of peroxisomes.

Option D: Grayanotoxins are produced by plants in the family Ericaceae. Consumption of the plant or any of its secondary products may result in intoxication characterized by dizziness, hypotension and atrial-ventricular block. This is also called Mad Honey disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with blood in his vomitus. He gives a history of binge drinking followed by multiple episodes of vomiting the prior night. He is hemodynamically stable.  Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: It is due to longitudinal mucosal tears
The gastroesophageal musculature fails to relax
The tears cross the gastroesophageal junction

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a Mallory–Weiss tear. They require only conservative management and healing tends to be rapid and complete.

They are longitudinal mucosal tears that may cross the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ). Forceful retching or vomiting along with failure of reflex relaxation of the gastroesophageal musculature results in tears involving the mucosa and submucosa. It usually occurs secondary to conditions like acute alcohol intoxication or hyperemesis gravidarum.

Boerhaave syndrome is a much more serious disorder characterized by transmural rupture of the distal esophagus. This results in acute mediastinitis with severe chest pain, tachypnea, and shock. Such patients generally require urgent surgical intervention.

questions.text: A man presents with severe vomiting. Homicidal poisoning is suspected as the vomitus appears luminous and emits a garlicky odor. Which of the following is most likely to be the poisoning agent?
questions.solution:
Luminous vomitus that gives off a garlicky odor is highly suggestive of white/yellow phosphorous poisoning.

White/yellow phosphorous is a waxy and translucent material that becomes luminous in the dark. It has a garlicky odor and taste. It gets oxidized on exposure to air, emits white fumes, and gets ignited at 34°C. It is highly toxic.

It is used in fertilizers, vermin-killers, rodenticides, fireworks, and gunpowder.

Stages of acute poisoning:

First stage: Intake causes severe abdominal discomfort, throat and abdominal pain, extreme thirst, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Excreta and breath have a garlic-like smell. Luminescent feces and vomit are characteristically seen. Skin contact results in second and third-degree burns that are deeply painful and take a long time to heal.

Second stage: This is a 2-3 days symptom-free period.

Third stage: There is hematemesis, enlargement of the liver, jaundice, pruritus, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and nausea. Shock, hepatic failure, injury to the central nervous system, hematemesis, and renal insufficiency are all potential causes of death.

Red phosphorus is characteristically odorless and is non-luminous.

Arsenic and thallium may also be associated with a garlicky odor; they are not characteristically associated with luminous vomitus.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A 1-year-old male child is brought with abdominal distension, recurrent pain, nausea, and vomiting. The vomitus was bilious, and the child had stiffened and pulled his legs up to the abdomen. Past history is insignificant. An ultrasound revealed the finding shown in the image. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of abdominal distention, recurrent abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, and the USG showing the doughnut sign (target sign) and pseudokidney sign are all suggestive of an intussusception.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocecal. 

The majority of cases of intussusception in children are idiopathic in nature. It can be seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a slightly increased risk of intussusception.

Clinical features include sudden, cramping abdominal pain associated with “currant jelly” stools and a palpable mass on physical examination. During the cramping episodes, the child may stiffen and pull the legs up to the abdomen. Between attacks, the child may appear comfortable. Normal bowel movements will stop as the obstruction progresses and become associated with bilious emesis and increasing abdominal distention. 

USG findings in intussusception include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)- The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands.
  • Pseudokidney sign is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma.

Treatment is mainly by hydrostatic reduction of intussusception by enema. It should be done immediately after the diagnosis.

Other options:

Option A: Acute gastroenteritis in children manifests as vomiting and/or diarrhoea, fever, abdominal pain, and anorexia. The most common cause of gastroenteritis in children is a viral infection, with the etiologic agents being rotaviruses, noroviruses, enteric adenoviruses, caliciviruses, astroviruses, and enteroviruses.

Option B: Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis presents with non-bilious vomiting that is projectile in nature and usually affects male infants between 2 and 8 weeks of age and is rarely seen after 13 weeks. An olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant. A test feed shows visible gastric peristalsis.

Option D: Hirschsprung's disease usually presents in the neonatal period with symptoms of delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension, and bilious vomiting; later, in adult life, it usually manifests as severe chronic constipation. It is characterized by the congenital absence of intramural ganglion cells in the distal large bowel.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and diarrhoea for the past few hours, and noticed blood in the stool during the recent episodes. He also had two episodes of vomiting. On evaluation, he has a temperature of 39ºC with clinical signs of dehydration. All of the following are indications to initiate empirical antibiotic therapy in this patient, except?
questions.solution:
Two episodes of vomiting are not an indication for antibiotic therapy.

Stool analysis and culture is the initial investigation of choice and antibiotic therapy should be instituted based on microbiological evidence. However, empirical antibiotic therapy may be initiated if diarrhoea persists even with anti-diarrhoeal agents when the patient has grossly bloody stools, fever > 38.5°C, is immunocompromised or is an elderly patient. The empirical antibiotics of choice are either metronidazole or fluoroquinolones.

In a patient with acute diarrhoea, the following are indications for further evaluation:

  1. Profuse diarrhoea with dehydration
  2. Fever > 38.5°C (101°F)
  3. Bloody stools (dysentery)
  4. Duration > 48 hours without improvement
  5. History of recent antibiotic use
  6. Patients aged>50 years with associated acute abdominal pain 
  7. Patients aged>70 years
  8. Immunocompromised patients

questions.text:
A woman has vomiting whenever she eats spicy food. Arrange the sequence of events during vomiting.
  1. LES is open and UES is closed.
  2. Strong contractions in the stomach.
  3. Inspiration against a closed glottis. 
  4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter. 
  5. LES opens and UES opens.
  6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine.

LES: Lower esophageal sphincter 

UES: Upper esophageal sphincter
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of vomiting is 6, 4, 2, 3, 1, 5.

6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine.
4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter. 
2. Strong contractions in the stomach.
3. Inspiration against a closed glottis. 
1. LES is open and UES is closed.
5. LES opens and UES opens.

The sensory signals that initiate vomiting are located in the pharynx, esophagus, stomach, and upper portions of the small intestines. Excessive distention or irritation of the duodenum provides a strong stimulus for vomiting. Area postrema constitutes the vomiting centre.

In the early stage, reverse peristalsis begins often minutes before vomiting. It begins far down in the ileum and travels up the intestine. This process pushes a large share of lower small intestine contents to the duodenum and stomach. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter occurs during this process.

At the onset of vomiting, strong intrinsic contractions are seen in the duodenum and stomach. Once the vomiting centre has been stimulated, inspiration occurs against the closed glottis. It prevents the flow of vomitus into the lungs. The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is open and the upper esophageal sphincter (UES) is closed at this stage.

The muscles of the abdominal wall contract, building intra-gastric pressure. Finally LES relaxes completely and UES also relaxes allowing the expulsion of the gastric contents.

Note: The esophageal smooth muscle functions as LES at the gastro-esophageal junction. It normally remains tonically constricted. Receptive relaxation of LES occurs when the peristaltic wave passes down the esophagus.

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative agent in the given scenario is enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which Type  A toxin is responsible for most cases.

Other options:

Option B: Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B.cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it.

Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types, namely diarrheal type and emetic type, caused by an enterotoxin and an emetic toxin respectively.

Bacillus cereus Diarrheal type Emetic type
Incubation period 8-16 hours 1-5 hours
Toxin Secreted in intestine Preformed
Heat Heat labile Heat stable
Food items Meat Rice
Clinical feature Diarrhea, abdominal cramps Vomiting, abdominal cramps

Option C: Verocytotoxin from E.coli is also known as Shiga-like toxin and it causes bloody diarrhea. It is produced by enterohemorrhagic E.Coli. It can cause illnesses ranging from mild diarrhea to fatal hemorrhagic colitis and hemorrhagic uremic syndrome.

Option D: Shiga toxin acts by inactivating 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. Shigella dysenteriae causes acute onset of symptoms(fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test and is non-lactose fermenting.

questions.text: A 25-year-old model who is on top of her game comes to get liposuction done. She says she is obese and would like to get rid of the "flabby tissue". On inquiry, it is revealed that she eats high-calorie food multiple times a month and regrets it afterward. She also sometimes skips meals. On examination, BMI is 23, and the finding shown below is noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows calluses and pigmentation on knuckles, known as Russell's sign. The given clinical history of binge-eating, body-image issues, Russell's sign along with a normal BMI is suggestive of bulimia nervosa.

The calluses on hands form due to the repeated scraping of knuckles on the teeth, during self-induced vomiting.

Bulimia can be differentiated from anorexia nervosa by the following features:

  • The body weight is within the normal range.
  • Bulimia is seen in older age groups (late adolescents or adults).
  • Any peculiar eating habit (like dividing food into small portions) is not seen.
  • Amenorrhoea is not common.
  • Psychiatric symptoms such as depression are more common.

Treatment of bulimia nervosa:

  • Without comorbid mood disorders- fluoxetine, topiramate, CBT
  • With comorbid mood disorders- carbamazepine

questions.text: A student on the college dance team was brought to the casualty after she got injured doing a back-flip. While eliciting her history, she revealed that she always feels cold and has not been getting her periods on time. On examination, she appeared pale and thin and had bilateral parotid swelling. Soft, fine hair was incidentally noted on her trunk and shoulders. Her BMI was 15. Lower limb X-ray revealed a left tibial fracture and generalized osteopenia. Further workup is likely to reveal which of the following abnormalities?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of anorexia nervosa. These patients have increased corticotropin-releasing hormone, increased cholesterol levels, decreased potassium levels, and decreased luteinizing hormone.

Features like low BMI, fracture in a young patient after trivial trauma (suggestive of osteoporosis), soft fine hair on the trunk (lanugo hair that occurs due to starvation), amenorrhea, bilateral parotid swelling (due to purging), and decreased tolerance to cold are strongly suggestive of anorexia nervosa.

Lab findings in anorexia nervosa:

  • Complete blood count- leukopenia with a relative lymphocytosis
  • Serum electrolyte- hypokalemic alkalosis (purging)
  • Fasting serum glucose- often low (emaciated phase)
  • Serum salivary amylase- often elevated (if the patient is vomiting)
  • ECG- ST-segment and T-wave changes (secondary to electrolyte disturbances)
  • Hypotension and bradycardia
  • Low LH and FSH
  • High serum cholesterol level
  • Increased GH levels
  • Endocrine changes (caused by the underweight):
    • Amenorrhea
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone
